title-wrap.full: Eurocode 2 - Design of concrete structures - Part 1-1: General rules and rules for buildings
Eurokode 2 - Prosjektering av betongkonstruksjoner - Del 1-1: Allmenne regler og regler for bygninger

app.label: National Annex NA
app.title: Nationally determined parameters for the use of NS-EN 1992-1-1 in Norway

sec.title: Foreword
sec.p: This revised National Annex, NS-EN 1992-1-1:2004+A1:2014/NA:2024, to NS-EN 1992-1-1:2004+A1:2014 Eurocode 2: Design of concrete structures – Part 1-1: General rules and rules for buildings, was adopted in xxx 2024.
This document supersedes NS-EN 1992-1-1:2004+A1:2014/NA:2021, and the following changes have been made to the document:

list-item.p: Tables NA.4.4N and NA.4.5N: Reduced requirement for minimum cover in exposure classes XC2, XC3, and XC4 when using durability class M45, as an alternative to the minimum requirement M60;
NA.9.5.2: The minimum area of longitudinal reinforcement As,min is set equal to the recommended value in the main part, and the minimum bar diameter ϕmin is increased from 10 to 12 mm;
NA.A.2.1: The material factor for concrete,γC,red1, is lowered from 1,5 to 1,4, which is the recommended value in the main part;

sec.p: This National Annex specifies the national determined provisions to be applied when using NS-EN 1992-1-1:2004+A1:2014 for structural design in Norway.
National choices are permitted in connection with the following subclauses in NS-EN 1992-1-1:2004+A1:2014:
All the provisions in this annex have the prefix «NA» to indicate that the provisions are a part of this National Annex.
In connection with some of the provision’s additional subclauses, figures or formulas may be given. These are numbered (901), (902), (903), (…) following the given numbering.
This document contains decision on the application of informative annexes.
This document may contain non-conflicting complementary information (NCCI).

sec.label: NA.2.3.3
sec.title: Deformations of concrete
sec.p: NA.2.3.3(3) The value of djoint may be assessed in each individual case. For pre-cast concrete structures, the effect on joints, e.g. corbels, is to be given special consideration.

sec.label: NA.2.4.2.1
sec.title: Partial factor for shrinkage action
sec.p: NA.2.4.2.1(1) The partial factor, γSH, is set equal to 1,0.

sec.label: NA.2.4.2.2
sec.title: Partial factors for prestress
sec.p: NA.2.4.2.2(1) The partial factor for prestress, γP,fav, is set equal to 0,9 or 1,1 where this is more unfavourable. In the verification of fatigue, the value of γP,fav is set equal to 1,0.
NA.2.4.2.2(2) In the verification of static equilibrium (EQU), the partial factor for external prestress, γP,unfav, is set equal to 1,3.

NA.2.4.2.2(3) In the verification of local effects, the partial factor for prestress, γP,unfav, is set equal to 1,1. For situations during tensioning, the stressing force is set equal to the maximum stressing force, Pmax, which should normally not be taken less than k3⋅fp0,1k⋅Ap.

sec.label: NA.2.4.2.3
sec.title: Partial factor for fatigue loads
sec.p: NA.2.4.2.3(1) In the calculation of fatigue loads, the partial factor, γF,fat, is set equal to 1,0.

sec.label: NA.2.4.2.4
sec.title: Partial factors for materials
sec.p: NA.2.4.2.4(1) Partial factors for materials for concrete and reinforcing steel in ultimate limit states are given in Table NA.2.1N.
If the conditions are met, the reduced partial factors for materials given in NA.A.2.2 may be used.

caption.title: Partial factors for materials for ultimate limit states

non-normative-note.label: NOTE
non-normative-note.p: The partial factors for materials given in Table NA.2.1N alternatively in clause NA.A.2.2 may be used in all reliability classes defined in the National Annex to NS-EN 1990 together with the given partial factors for actions, provided that supervision of design and inspection of execution is conducted as described.

sec.p: NA.2.4.2.4(2) Partial factors for materials for concrete and reinforcing steel in serviceability limit states are set equal to 1,0, unless otherwise specified in the standard.

sec.label: NA2.4.25
sec.title: Partial factors for materials for foundations
sec.p: NA.2.4.2.5(2) The factor, kf, is set equal to 1,1.

sec.label: NA.3.1.2
sec.title: Strength
sec.p: NA.3.1.2(2) The highest strength class, Cmax, is set equal to B95 equivalent to C95/110. The same strain values may be used as those given for C90/105 in Table 3.1.

non-normative-note.label: NOTE
non-normative-note.p: Normally utilised strength classes in Norway are given in the National Annex to NS-EN 206; the term designates the cylinder strength of the concrete with the prefix ”B” for normal weight concrete and heavy aggregate concrete and ”LB” for lightweight aggregate concrete.

td.p: Strength class normal weight concrete and heavy aggregate concrete

sec.p: NA.3.1.2(4) The factor, kt, is set equal to 1/βcc(t) ≤ 1,0, where βcc(t) is given by formula (3.2).

sec.label: NA.3.1.6
sec.title: Design compressive and tensile strengths
sec.p: NA.3.1.6(1)P The coefficient, αcc, is set equal to 0,85.
NA.3.1.6(2)P The coefficient, αct, is set equal to 0,85.

non-normative-note.label: NOTE
non-normative-note.p: In NS-EN 1992, it is assumed that reinforcing steel in accordance with NS-EN 10080 is used. It specifies the various types of properties for reinforcement (see also 3.2.2(1)P) and the ways in which these are tested, but with only a few exceptions it does not set requirements for those properties. However, such requirements are given in clauses 3.2.2 to 3.2.6 of this standard and in Annex C. Reinforcement in accordance with NS 3576 may be considered to meet these requirements.

sec.label: NA.3.2.2
sec.title: Properties (reinforcing steel)
sec.p: NA.3.2.2(3)P The upper limit of fyk is set equal to 600 MPa.

sec.label: NA.3.2.7
sec.title: Design assumptions (reinforcing steel)
sec.p: NA.3.2.7(2) When using method a), values in Table NA.3.5 (901) may be used.

caption.title: Design ultimate strain, εud, depending on technical class

p.bold: The ultimate strain of the reinforcing steel
Design strength at the ultimate strain

fn.p: The values may be used for B500NC even when the values in NS 3576-3 deviate somewhat from the values in Annex C.
For reinforcing steel with an especially high ultimate strain, such as certain types of stainless steel reinforcement, the increased hardening is disregarded, which corresponds to method b).

sec.p: For reinforcement where Agt has a known value, the design ultimate strain εud may be set equal to 0,4εuk.

sec.label: NA.3.3.4
sec.title: Ductility characteristics
sec.p: NA.3.3.4(5) The factor, k, is set equal to 1,1.

sec.label: NA.3.3.6
sec.title: Design assumptions
sec.p: NA.3.3.6(7) The strain limit, εud, may be set equal to the larger of 0,01 and 0,4εuk; the associated stress is set less than or equal to 1,04fp0,1k/γS unless the ratio fpk/fp0,1k is known and greater than 1,1.

non-normative-note.label: NOTE 1
non-normative-note.p: In Norway, two additional exposure classes, Groups 7 and 8, are defined. In addition there are other examples for classes X0 and XC1 and a footnote to exposure class XD3; see NS-EN 206/NA

non-normative-note.label: NOTE 2
non-normative-note.p: Structures under roof where chlorides are not washed away can experience increased concentrations of chlorides on the surface. See footnote a) in Table NA.4.1 (902).

caption.title: Additional exposure classes 7 and 8, examples related to exposure classes X0 and XC1 and footnote to exposure class XD3 as defined in the National Annex to NS-EN 206

p.bold: Informative examples where exposure classes may occur (informative)
1 No risk of corrosion or attack

td.p: For concrete without reinforcement or embedded metal: all exposures except where there is freeze/thaw, abrasion or chemical attack
For concrete with reinforcement or embedded metal: very dry
Indoor concrete in dry, heated rooms
Indoor concrete in dry, unheated rooms
Parts of bridges exposed to spray containing chlorides
Car park structures in contact with chlorides
Structures such as floor slats for livestock, manure cellars, etc.

Structures exposed to strong chemical attack that are not covered by any of the other exposure classes and that make it necessary to require special protective measures. This may require concrete of a special mix composition, protective membranes, etc.
Structures that, among other things, are in contact with liquids with high sulphate content or a low pH, such as alum shale, feed silos, etc.

fn.p: Where chlorides enrich on surface special measures need to be considered such as increased concrete cover or using a membrane.

sec.label: NA.4.4.1.2
sec.title: Minimum cover cmin
sec.p: NA.4.4.1.2(3) Minimum cover due to bond requirement, cmin,b, is specified in Table NA.4.2.

caption.title: Minimum cover, cmin,b, requirements with regard to bond

td.p: Diameter of bar, but not less than 10 mm
The lesser of the duct diameter and 80 mm
The greater of the smaller dimension or half the greater dimension, but not more than 80 mm
Pre-tensioned tendon: strand or plain wire

fn.p: If the nominal maximum aggregate size is greater than 32 mm, cmin,b should be increased by 5 mm.

sec.p: NA.4.4.1.2(5) The minimum cover values for reinforcement and pre-stressing tendons with regard to durability cmin,dur are given in Table NA.4.4N and Table NA.4.5N respectively.

It is assumed that durability classes, as specified in the National Annex to NS-EN 206, are utilised as indicated by the tables and that the chloride content of the concrete is limited, see clause 4.2(3). For cement adhesive, mortar and concrete that comes in contact with pre-stressing steel in reinforced concrete structures that are manufactured with sulphate-resistant cement and concrete structures in especially chloride-rich environments (seawater, de-icing salt, etc.), chloride class Cl 0,10 shall be used. For other reinforced concrete structures, chloride class Cl 0,40 or better shall be used, with regard to durability it is recommended to use Cl 0,2. For structures without reinforcement or other encased metal, chloride class Cl 1,0 may be used.

caption.title: Values of minimum cover, cmin,dur, requirements with regard to durability for reinforcement steel in accordance with NS-EN 10080

fn.p: The choice of durability class for the exposure classes XF, XA and XSA shall be in accordance with NS‑EN 206:2013+A1:2016+NA. For classes XA3 and XA4 the cover should normally not be less than 40 mm for 50 years design working life respectively 50 mm for 100 years, for class XSA the complete set of measures shall be given special consideration.
If the environmental impact is classified in multiple exposure classes, the concrete shall meet the requirements of all associated durability classes.

Reduced cover shall not be used when using cement type CEM III/A or CEM III/B (see NS-EN 206:2013+A2:2021/NA:2022, table NA.12) in durability class M45 as an alternative to the minimum requirement M60.

caption.title: Values of minimum cover, cmin,dur, requirements with regard to durability for prestressing steel

sec.p: NA.4.4.1.2(6) The value of Δcdur,γ is normally set equal to 0 mm. Higher values may be considered in special cases where there is a particular need to reduce the probability of corrosion damage to the reinforcement.

non-normative-note.label: NOTE
non-normative-note.p: Where it is relevant to consider an increased design working life or a reduced acceptance value for possible corrosion, reference is made to the specialist-literature in the area. The requirements for cover given in Table NA.4.4N and Table NA.4.5N are in accordance with the safety requirements for irreversible serviceability limit states in NS-EN 1990:2002+A1:2005 Annex B and Annex C. A value for Δcdur,γ equal to 10 mm will give a considerable increase in the design working life for an unchanged probability of corrosion damage, or a considerable reduction in the probability of corrosion damage for an unchanged design working life.

sec.p: NA.4.4.1.2(7) The value of Δcdur,st is normally set equal to 0 mm. Depending on the nobility of the steel, higher values may be used based on methods described in specialist-literature, but not greater than 15 mm.
NA.4.4.1.2(8) The value of Δcdur,add is normally set equal to 0 mm. A higher value may be considered based on the protective measures in each individual case.
NA.4.4.1.2(13) No value is given for the quantities k1, k2, k3. A possible increase of the cover should be considered in each individual case.

sec.label: NA.4.4.1.3
sec.title: Allowance in design for deviation
sec.p: NA.4.4.1.3(1)P The allowance in design for the maximum negative deviation Δcdev is set equal to 10 mm. Higher values may be chosen.
NA.4.4.1.3(3) The allowance in design for the maximum negative deviation Δcdev may be reduced to 5 mm if the following requirements are met:

list-item.p: fabrication is subjected to a quality assurance system, in which the monitoring includes measurements of the concrete cover;
a very accurate measurement device is used for monitoring and non-conforming members are rejected and/or repaired.

sec.p: NA.4.4.1.3(4) The minimum nominal cover, k1, is set equal to 40 mm and the minimum nominal cover, k2, is set equal to 75 mm. For soft ground, measures shall be prescribed to prevent the reinforcement from being pressed down into the ground.

sec.label: NA.5.1.3
sec.title: Load cases and combinations
sec.p: NA.5.1.3(1)P Calculations shall be carried out so that the requirements in (1)P are met. For continuous beams and one-way slabs where the ratio between adjacent spans is approximately 1,0, two situations may be considered:

list-item.p: variable action in alternate spans, combination of actions in accordance with NS-EN 1990:2002+A1:2005 formula 6.10a and 6.10b;
variable action in two adjacent spans, combination of actions in accordance with NS-EN 1990:2002+A1:2005 formula 6.10a and 6.10b.

sec.label: NA.5.2
sec.title: Geometric imperfections
sec.p: NA.5.2(5) The basic value θ0 is set equal to 1/200.

sec.label: NA.5.5
sec.title: Linear elastic analysis with limited redistribution
sec.p: NA.5.5(4) The factors to be used in formula
5.10a and 5.10b are given the following values:

list-item.p: k2 and k4 are set equal to 1,25(0,6 + 0,0014/εcu2);

sec.p: εcu2 is the ultimate strain according to Table 3.1.

sec.label: NA.5.6.3
sec.title: Rotation capacity
sec.p: NA.5.6.3(4) The basic value of allowable rotation θpl,d for reinforcement in accordance with NS 3576 classes NB and NC is given in Figure NA.5.6N. The values may also be used for reinforcement in accordance with NS-EN 10080 that meets the requirements for class B and C steel in Table C.1.

caption.title: Basic value of allowable rotation θpl,d of reinforced concrete sections for Class B and C reinforcement. The values apply for a shear slenderness λ = 3,0.

sec.label: NA.5.8.3.1
sec.title: Slenderness criterion for isolated members
sec.p: NA.5.8.3.1(1) The condition that would allow second order effects to be ignored are met if:
λn ≤ λn,lim
where λn,lim is defined depending on:
for compression members where the ends are braced and that do not have transverse load.:
for compression members where one end is unbraced and for compression members that have transverse load:

def.p: = M01/M02 is the ratio between the numerically least and numerically greatest first order end moments. Where M02 < NEd·h/20, rm is set equal to 1. rm should be taken positive if the end moments M01 and M02 give tension on the same side.

sec.p: Normalised slenderness λn is defined by

def.p: = (is/i)2 where is is the radius of gyration of the reinforcement and i is the radius of gyration of the uncracked concrete section. As a simplification, ka may normally be set equal to 1.

sec.label: NA.5.8.3.3
sec.title: Global second order effects in buildings
sec.p: NA.5.8.3.3(1) The factor k1 is set equal to 0,3.
NA.5.8.3.3(2) The factor k2 is set equal to 0,6.

sec.label: NA.5.8.5
sec.title: Methods of analysis
sec.p: NA.5.8.5(1) Method (a) and method (b) may be used.

sec.label: NA.5.8.6
sec.title: General method
sec.p: NA.5.8.6(3) The partial factor, γCE, is set equal to 1,2.

sec.label: NA.5.10.1
sec.title: General (prestressed members and structures)
sec.p: NA.5.10.1(6) Methods A, B and E may be used in order to meet the requirements in (5)P. In some cases, Method C may be necessary as a supplement to methods A, B and E. Method D shall always be used, but is not sufficient on its own.

sec.label: NA.5.10.2.1
sec.title: Maximum stressing force
sec.p: NA.5.10.2.1(1)P The factor k1 is set equal to 0,8, and the factor k2 is set equal to 0,9.
NA.5.10.2.1(2) The factor k3 is set equal to 0,95.

sec.label: NA.5.10.2.2
sec.title: Limitation of concrete stress
sec.p: NA.5.10.2.2(4) The factor k4 is set equal to 50, and the factor k5 is set equal to 30.
NA.5.10.2.2(5) The factor k6 is set equal to 0,7.

sec.label: NA.5.10.3
sec.title: Prestress force
sec.p: NA.5.10.3(2) The factor k7 is set equal to 0,75, and the factor k8 is set equal to 0,85.

sec.label: NA.5.10.8
sec.title: Effects of prestressing at ultimate limit state
sec.p: NA.5.10.8(2) The increase of the stress, Δσp,ULS, may be assumed to be 100 MPa provided that the tendons are located on the tension side both in spans and above supports.
NA.5.10.8(3) The most unfavourable of the factors γΔP,sup and γΔP,inf is the one to be used.

If the calculation of deformations is performed assuming a cracked section, γΔP,sup is set equal to 1,2, and γΔP,inf is set equal to 0,8. If the deformations are calculated assuming an uncracked section, γΔP,sup and γΔP,inf may be set equal to 1,0.

sec.label: NA.5.10.9
sec.title: Effects of prestressing at serviceability limit state and limit state of fatigue
sec.p: NA.5.10.9(1)P The factors rsup and rinf may be set equal to 1,0 if the stressing force Pm,t(x) is calculated at the time t equal to the design working life of the structure. If not, rsup is set equal to 1,05 and rinf is set equal 0,95 for both pre-tensioned and post-tensioned systems.

sec.label: NA.6.2.2
sec.title: Members not requiring design shear reinforcement
sec.p: NA.6.2.2(1) The factor CRd,c is set equal to k2/γC

def.p: = 0,15 if the conditions for using k2 equals 0,18 are not met

= 0,18 for concrete with the maximum size of aggregate D, according to NS-EN 12620, greater than or equal to 16 mm, and where the coarse aggregate constitutes (approximately) 50% or more of the total content of aggregate and where coarse aggregates with a low strength (fragmentation coefficient LA > LA40 for concrete strength above B35, otherwise LA > LA50) are not used.

sec.p: The factor k1 is set equal to 0,15 for compression and equal to 0,3 for tension (σcp negative for tension).
The minimum shear resistance associated with principal tensile failure, νmin, is determined as:
It is assumed that fck is not given a value greater than 65 MPa in formulae (6.2.a) and (6.3N).

non-normative-note.label: NOTE
non-normative-note.p: Design shear force vEd is normally set equal to the principal shear force vres = (vEd,x2 + vEd,y2)0,5; it can, however, be dimensioned independently in the two directions if the ratio between the minimum and the maximum shear force is not greater than 0,5.

sec.p: NA.6.2.2(6) The factor ν is determined as:

sec.label: NA.6.2.3
sec.title: Members requiring design shear reinforcement
sec.p: NA.6.2.3(2) The value of cotθ may be chosen in the range determined by formula (NA.6.7.aN), except in sections with significant axial tension (σt = NEd/Ac ≥ fctk, 0,05). There cotθ is determined by the formula (NA.6.7.bN).

NA.6.2.3(3) The factor ν1 may be set equal to ν determined by formula NA.6.6N. If the tension in the shear reinforcement is less than 0,8fyk, ν1 may be determined on the basis of formulas (NA.6.10.aN) and (NA.6.10.bN).

The factor αcw is set equal to 1 in structures without prestressing or axial compression. In structures with prestressing or axial compression, αcw is determined on the basis of the formulas (NA.6.11.aN), (NA.6.11.bN) and (NA.6.11.cN).
where σcp is the mean compressive stress, which is specified in greater detail in note 3 of the standard.

sec.label: NA.6.2.4
sec.title: Shear between web and flanges of T-sections
sec.p: NA.6.2.4(4) The value of cotθ may be chosen in the range determined by formulas (NA.6.7.aN) and (NA.6.7.bN):
NA.6.2.4(6) The factor k is set equal to 0,4.

sec.label: NA.6.4.3
sec.title: Punching shear calculation
sec.p: NA.6.4.3(6) Simplified values of the factor β are given in Figure NA.6.21N.

sec.label: NA.6.4.4
sec.title: Punching shear resistance of slabs and column bases without shear reinforcement
sec.p: NA.6.4.4(1) The factor CRd,c is set equal to k2/γC

def.p: = 0,15 if the conditions for using k2 equals 0,18 are not met

= 0,18 for concrete with the maximum size of aggregate D, according to NS-EN 12620, greater than or equal to 16 mm, and where the coarse aggregate constitutes (approximately) 50% or more of the total content of aggregate and where coarse aggregates with a low strength (fragmentation coefficient LA > LA40 for concrete strength above B35, otherwise LA > LA50) are not used.

sec.p: The factor k1 is set equal to 0,1 for compression and equal to 0,3 for tension (σcp negative for tension).
The minimum shear resistance associated with principal tensile failure, νmin, is determined as:
It is assumed that fck is not given a value greater than 65 MPa in formulas (6.47) and (6.3N).

sec.label: NA.6.4.5
sec.title: Punching shear resistance of slabs and column bases with shear reinforcement
sec.p: NA.6.4.5(1) The value of kmax is set equal to 1,5 for stirrups and 1,8 for bolts/rods with T-heads or reinforcement ladders with documented capacity as shear reinforcement, stirrups and bolts/rods with T‑heads are anchored around the tension reinforcement, see 9.2.2(2). The value of kmax is also used for light weight aggregate concrete in formula (11.6.52)

NA.6.4.5(3) The value of vRd,max is set equal to 0,4νfcd, this also apply to structures of lightweight aggregate concrete, but with the relevant strength values for lightweight aggregate concrete, see NA.11.6.4.2(2).
NA.6.4.5(4) The factor k is set equal to 1,0.

sec.label: NA.6.5.2
sec.title: Struts
sec.p: NA.6.5(2) The factor ν’ is set equal to (1 - fck/250).

sec.label: NA.6.5.4
sec.title: Nodes

list-item.label: a)
list-item.p: the factor k1 is set equal to 1,0.;

list-item.label: b)
list-item.p: the factor k2 is set equal to 0,85;

list-item.label: c)
list-item.p: the factor k3 is set equal to 0,75.

sec.p: NA.6.5.4(6) The factor k4 is set equal to 3,0.

sec.label: NA.6.8.4
sec.title: Verification procedure for reinforcing and prestressing steel
sec.p: NA.6.8.4(1) The value of γF,fat is set equal to 1,0.
The parameters that describe the S-N curve of the steel are given in Table NA.6.3N for ordinary reinforcing steel and in Table NA.6.4N for prestressing steel.

caption.title: Parameters for S-N curves for reinforcing steel

fn.p: Values for ΔσRsk are those for straight bars. Values for bent bars should be obtained using a reduction factor ζ = 0,35 + 0,026 D /ϕ, where D is the diameter of the mandrel and ϕ is the bar diameter.

caption.title: Parameters for S-N curves of prestressing steel

p.bold: S-N-curve of pre-stressing steel used for

list-item.p: straight tendons or curved tendons in plastic ducts

sec.p: NA.6.8.4(5) The factor k2 is set equal to 5.

sec.label: NA.6.8.6
sec.title: Other verifications
sec.p: NA.6.8.6(1) The value of k1 is set equal to 70 MPa, and the value of k2 is set equal to 35 MPa.
NA.6.8.6(3) The value of k3 is set equal to 0,9.

sec.label: NA.6.8.7
sec.title: Verification of concrete under compression or shear
sec.p: NA.6.8.7(1) The number of cycles N is set equal to 106. The factor k1 is set equal to 0,85 when the whole section is under compression. Where parts of the section are under tension, the factor k1 may be set equal to 1,0.

sec.label: NA.7.2
sec.title: Stress limitation
sec.p: NA.7.2(2) The factor k1 is set equal to 0,6.
NA.7.2(3) The factor k2 is set equal to 0,45.
NA.7.2(5) The factor k3 is set equal to 0,8. The factor k4 is set equal to 1,0, and the factor k5 is set equal to 0,75.

sec.label: NA.7.3.1
sec.title: General considerations (crack control)
sec.p: NA.7.3.1(5) Out of consideration for the durability of the structure, the calculated crack width, wk, is limited taking into account the environmental exposure conditions of the structure. The limiting calculated crack width, wmax, is given in Table NA.7.1N for the calculated value of wk. Here the factor, kc, takes into account the effect of greater cover than the requirement for cmin,dur and is determined by the formula:

p.bold: Reinforced members and prestressed members with unbonded tendons

fn.p: Where the pre-stressing steel lies within a layer of ordinary reinforcement, the calculated crack width must meet the requirements for both ordinary reinforcement and pre-stressing steel. For verification against the requirement for prestressing steel the frequent load combinations are used, the calculated crack width may be adjusted with the formula w2k = wk (εs2 / εs1), where εs1 is the tensile strain in the reinforcement on the side with greatest strain, εs2 is the tensile strain at the level of the prestressing steel and w2k is an adjusted calculated crack width that is compared with the limiting values in the table.
For the X0 exposure class, crack width has no influence on durability, and this limit is set to guarantee acceptable appearance. In the absence of appearance conditions, this limit may be relaxed.

Where verification that decompression does not occur is required, the whole section of pre-stressing steel and where relevant the duct for post-tensioned tendons, should lie at least Δcdev within the compression zone.

A total assessment is necessary in these cases in order to arrive at an appropriate combination of structural detailing, material composition, cover, limitation of crack width and other protective measures.

sec.label: NA.7.3.2
sec.title: Minimum reinforcement areas
sec.p: NA.7.3.2(4) The value of σct,p is set equal to lik fctk,05, or alternatively lik fctk,05 (t), if the cracking can occur before the 28-day strength has been achieved in the structure. For structures in exposure classes XD and XS, σct,p is set equal to zero.

sec.label: NA.7.3.4
sec.title: Calculation of crack widths
sec.p: NA.7.3.4(3) The factor k3 is set equal to 3,4, the factor k4 is set equal to 0,425, and the value of Ac,eff is set not less than a value that corresponds to hc,eff equal to (h – d + 1,5ϕ), see 7.3.2(3).

sec.label: NA.7.4.2
sec.title: Cases where calculations may be omitted
sec.p: NA.7.4.2(2) Values for the factor, K, are given in Table NA.7.4N.

caption.title: Factor K where checking if calculation of deflections may be omitted

td.p: Simply supported beam, one- or two-way spanning simply supported slab
End span of continuous beam or one-way continuous slab or two-way spanning slab continuous over one long side
Interior span of beam or one-way or two-way spanning slab
Slab supported on columns without beams (flat slab) (based on longer span)

sec.label: NA.8.2
sec.title: Spacing of bars
sec.p: NA.8.2(2) The factor k1 is set equal to 2,0 for bars in the same layer, and k1 is set equal to 1,5 for the space between different layers. However, the space between the layers does not need to be set greater than 32 mm for bars or bundles that are less than or equal to ϕlarge. The value of k2 is set equal to 5 mm.

sec.label: NA.8.3
sec.title: Permissible mandrel diameters for bent bars
sec.p: NA.8.3(2) The minimum permitted mandrel diameter ϕm,min is determined in order to avoid damage to the reinforcement and failure of the concrete caused by the deviatory stresses from the reinforcement. The mandrel diameter ϕm,min shall not be less than the larger of the value given in Table NA.8.1N and the value determined by formula (8.1).
For bending of reinforcing steel in accordance with NS 3576, values given in Table NA.8.1N.c) may be used. For bars that are to be bent or straightened, values in Table NA.8.1N.a) may be used.
For the use of reinforcement other than in accordance with NS 3576, the values ascribed to ϕm,min given in Table NA.8.1N.a) shall be used.
For welded bent reinforcement or mesh, the values ascribed to ϕm,min given in Table NA.8.1N.b) shall be used.

caption.title: Minimum mandrel diameter ϕm,min to avoid damage to reinforcement
For bars and wire in accordance with NS-EN 10080, but that are not in accordance with NS 3576

td.p: Minimum permitted mandrel diameter, ϕm,min for bends, hooks, loops (see Figure 8.1) and stirrups
Minimum permitted mandrel diameter in the recommended Renard series
Minimum permitted mandrel diameter in the recommended Renard series for bars that are to be bent and straightened (the temperature shall be no lower than 0 ºC)

caption.title: For welded bent reinforcement and mesh bent after welding

td.p: d < 3ϕ or welding within the curved zonea: 20 ϕ

fn.p: The mandrel size for welding within the curved zone may be reduced to 5ϕ where the welding is carried out in accordance with NS-EN ISO 17660.

caption.title: For bars and wire in accordance with NS 3576

td.p: Minimum permitted mandrel diameter, ϕm,min for bends, hooks, loops (see Figure 8.1) and stirrups

fn.p: Hot-rolled ribbed bars of types B500NB and B500NC, manufactured with controlled cooling and annealing, may be bent at temperatures down to –20 ºC.
For reinforcement type B500NB, the mandrel diameter given in the top line may be used for bending at temperatures above 0 ºC.

sec.label: NA.8.6
sec.title: Anchorage by welded bars
sec.p: NA.8.6(2) The anchorage capacity of one welded transverse bar is given by the formula:

def.p: is the design shear strength of weld, but is not taken greater than 0,5 times the tension resistance of the anchored bar (0,5As fyd)

sec.p: Other parameters are as specified in the note.

sec.label: NA.8.8
sec.title: Additional rules for large diameter bars
sec.p: NA.8.8(1) The value of ϕlarge is set equal to 32 mm for bars and 40 mm for bundles.

sec.label: NA.9.2.1.1
sec.title: Minimum and maximum reinforcement areas
sec.p: NA.9.2.1.1(1) The minimum area of reinforcement, As,min, is determined by the formula
This provision applies to beams and slabs. Where special emphasis is given to the tightness (see NS EN 1992-3) of slabs, the minimum area of reinforcement should be at least twice as large.
The value of As,min is not reduced for secondary members.
NA.9.2.1.1(3) The maximum reinforcement area As,max is set equal to 0,04 Ac.

sec.label: NA.9.2.1.2
sec.title: Other detailing arrangements
sec.p: NA.9.2.1.2(1) The factor β1 is set equal to 0,15.

sec.label: NA.9.2.1.4
sec.title: Anchorage of bottom reinforcement at an end support
sec.p: NA.9.2.1.4 (1) The factor β2 is set equal to 0,25. This value is also used at supports with continuity and for fixed ends (see 9.2.1.5(1)).

sec.label: NA.9.2.2
sec.title: Shear reinforcement
sec.p: NA.9.2.2(4) The factor β3 is set equal to 0,5. However, the contribution of links to the shear reinforcement shall be no less than ρw,min, which is determined by the formula (NA.9.5N).
NA.9.2.2(5) The minimum shear reinforcement ratio, ρw,min, shall take the form of links. The area is determined by the formula
Beams with a depth greater than 1000 mm shall be provided with a longitudinal surface reinforcement as indicated in NA.9.7(1).
NA.9.2.2(6) The maximum longitudinal spacing between shear assemblies, sl,max, is determined by the formula:
where h’ is the distance between lines of gravity of the tension reinforcement and the compression reinforcement.
NA.9.2.2(7) The maximum longitudinal spacing between bent bars, sb,max, is determined by the formula:
where h’ is the distance between lines of gravity of the tension reinforcement and the compression reinforcement.
NA.9.2.2(8) The maximum transverse spacing between shear assemblies, st,max, is determined by the formula:

sec.label: NA.9.3.1.1
sec.title: General (flexural reinforcement)
sec.p: NA.9.3.1.1(3) The maximum spacing of bars, smax,slab, is set equal to:
In areas with concentrated loads or areas of maximum moment (span and supports), smax,slab is set equal to
Reinforcement that is required structurally is regarded here as principal reinforcement.

sec.label: NA.9.5.2
sec.title: Longitudinal reinforcement
sec.p: NA.9.5.2(1) The minimum bar diameter ϕmin is set equal to 12 mm.
NA.9.5.2(2) The minimum area of longitudinal reinforcement, As,min, is determined by the formula

mml:math.mml:mtext: , depending on which value is the greatest

sec.p: NA.9.5.2(3) The maximum area of longitudinal reinforcement, As,max, is set equal to 0,08Ac. This also includes any lapped bars at lapped splices. Where As is greater than 0,04Ac, the net cross-sectional area of concrete shall be used in the calculations.

sec.label: NA.9.5.3
sec.title: Transverse reinforcement
sec.p: NA.9.5.3(3) The maximum spacing between transverse reinforcement, scl,tmax, is set equal to the least of:

list-item.p: 15 times the minimum diameter of the longitudinal bars;
the lesser dimension of the column;

sec.p: If the area of longitudinal reinforcement exceeds 0,04Ac, or concrete in strength class B55 or higher is used, the spacing shall be reduced by a factor of 0,6.

The spacing of links shall be reduced in the same way in primary seismic columns in structures that are only designed according to the provisions in NS-EN 1992-1-1 where ag S > 0,1g , see NS-EN 1998-1 NA.3.2.1(4).

sec.label: NA.9.6.2
sec.title: Vertical reinforcement
sec.p: NA.9.6(1) The minimum area of vertical reinforcement, As,vmin, is set equal to 0,002Ac. Where special emphasis is given to the tightness (see NS-EN 1992-3), the reinforcement should be at least twice as large.

The maximum area of reinforcement outside lap locations, As,vmax is set equal to 0,04Ac. This area can be doubled at lapped splices if these are located at braced nodes; otherwise laps shall be staggered.

sec.label: NA.9.6.3
sec.title: Horizontal reinforcement
sec.p: NA.9.6.3(1) The minimum area of reinforcement on each side of doubly reinforced walls, As,hmin, is set equal to the largest of 25% of the vertical reinforcement on the same side or 0,3Ac fctm/fyk for exterior walls and 0,15Ac fctm/fyk for interior walls. Singly reinforced walls shall have an equivalent total area of reinforcement.
When special emphasis is given to tightness (see NS-EN 1992-3), the minimum area of reinforcement is determined by formula (7.1) with fct,eff equal to fctm and the factors, k and kc, equal to 1,0.

sec.label: NA.9.7
sec.title: Deep beams
sec.p: NA.9.7(1) The minimum area of reinforcement in deep beams on each side and in both directions, As,dbmin, is set equal to 0,001Ac, but not less than 150 mm2/m. Beams with a depth greater than 1000 mm shall be provided with a longitudinal surface reinforcement on both faces with at least a corresponding area, independent of the definition of deep beams in clause 5.3.1(3); see the provisions in 7.3.3(3) as well.

Plates and shells that are calculated and designed according to the theory of elasticity for forces in their plane (see Annex F) should not have less reinforcement on each face in the main directions than 0,3Ac fctm/fyk.

sec.label: NA.9.8.1
sec.title: Pile caps
sec.p: NA.9.8.1(3) The minimum bar diameter ϕmin is set equal to 8 mm.

sec.label: NA.9.8.2.1
sec.title: General (column and wall footings)
sec.p: NA.9.8.2.1(1) The minimum bar diameter ϕmin is set equal to 8 mm.

sec.label: NA.9.8.3
sec.title: Tie beams
sec.p: NA.9.8.3(1) The minimum bar diameter ϕmin is set equal to 8 mm.
NA.9.8.3(2) The minimum downward load q1 is assessed in each individual case. Normally, it is set no lower than 10 kN/m.

sec.label: NA.9.8.4
sec.title: Column footing on rock
sec.p: NA.9.8.4(1) The value of the contact pressure, q2, is set equal to 5 MPa. The minimum bar diameter ϕmin is set equal to 8 mm.

sec.label: NA.9.8.5
sec.title: Bored piles
sec.p: NA.9.8.5(3) Bored piles shall have the same minimum area of longitudinal reinforcement As,bpmin as for columns, specified in clause NA.9.5.2(2). The reinforcement is distributed evenly around the circumference. The minimum bar diameter is 16 mm. There shall be a minimum of 6 bars, and the free spacing between the bars shall not exceed 200 mm.

sec.label: NA.9.10.2.2
sec.title: Peripheral ties
sec.p: NA.9.10.2.2(2) The value of q1 is set equal to 10 kN/m, and the value of Q2 is set equal to 70 kN.

sec.label: NA.9.10.2.3
sec.title: Internal ties
sec.p: NA.9.10.2.3(3) The value of Ftie,int is set equal to 20 kN/m.
NA.9.10.2.3(4) The value of q3 is set equal to 20 kN/m, and the value of Q4 is set equal to 70 kN.

sec.label: NA.9.10.2.4
sec.title: Horizontal ties to columns and/or walls
sec.p: NA.9.10.2.4(2) The value of ftie,fac is set equal to 20 kN/m, and the value of Ftie,col is set equal to 150 kN.

sec.label: NA.11.3.5
sec.title: Design compressive and tensile strengths
sec.p: NA.11.3.5(1)P The factor αlcc is set equal to 0,85.
NA.11.3.5(2)P The factor αlct is set equal to 0,85.

sec.label: NA.11.3.7
sec.title: Confined concrete
sec.p: NA.11.3.7(1) The factor k is set equal to 1,0.

sec.label: NA.11.6.1
sec.title: Members not requiring design shear reinforcement
sec.p: NA.11.6.1(1) The factor ClRd,c is set equal to 0,15/γC .
The factor k1 is set equal to 0,15 for compression and equal to 0,3 for tension (σcp negative for tension).
The minimum shear resistance associated with principle tensile failure, νl,min, is determined as:
It is assumed that flck is not given a value greater than 55 MPa in formulas (11.6.2) and (NA.11.6.3).

sec.label: NA.11.6.2
sec.title: Members requiring design shear reinforcement
sec.p: NA.11.6.2.(1) The factor νl follows from:

sec.label: NA.11.6.4.1
sec.title: Punching shear resistance of slabs or column bases without shear reinforcement
sec.p: NA.11.6.4.1(1) The factor k2 is set equal to 0,08 for compression and equal to 0,3 for tension.

sec.label: NA.11.6.4.2
sec.title: Punching shear resistance of slabs or column bases with shear reinforcement
sec.p: NA.11.6.4.2(2) The value, v lRd,max is set equal to 0,4νl flcd as specified in NA.6.4.5(3).

sec.label: NA.12.3.1
sec.title: Concrete: additional design assumptions
sec.p: NA.12.3.1(1) The factors, αcc,pl and αct,pl, are set equal to 0,8.

sec.label: NA.12.6.3
sec.title: Shear
sec.p: NA.12.6.3(2) The factor k is set equal to 1,5.

sec.label: NA.A.2.1
sec.title: Reduction based on quality control and reduced deviations
sec.p: NA.A.2.1(1) The partial safety factor for reinforcement, γS,red1, is set equal to γS equals 1,15.
NA.A.2.1(2) The partial safety factor for concrete, γC,red1,is set equal to γC equals 1,4.

sec.label: NA.A.2.2
sec.title: Reduction based on using reduced or measured geometrical data in design
sec.p: NA.A.2.2(1) The partial safety factor for reinforcement, γS,red2,may be set equal to 1,1.
The partial safety factor for concrete, γC,red2,is set equal to γC equal to 1,5.
NA.A.2.2(2) The partial safety factor for concrete, γC,red3,may be set equal to 1,35.

sec.label: NA.A.2.3
sec.title: Reduction based on assessment of concrete strength in finished structure
sec.p: NA.A.2.3(1) The factor, η, may be set equal to 0,85 so that γC,red4 may be set equal to 1,3.

sec.label: NA.C.1
sec.title: General (properties of reinforcement suitable for use with this Eurocode)
sec.p: NA.C.1(1) Reinforcement in accordance with NS 3576-2 and NS 3576-3 may be regarded as having adequate fatigue properties to meet the requirements in Annex C.
Reinforcement in accordance with NS 3576 may be regarded as having adequate relative rib area.
Reinforcement in accordance with NS-EN 10080 shall at least meet the requirements in Table NA.C.2N.

td.p: (for N ≥ 2 x 106 cycles) with an upper limit of 0,6fyk

sec.p: NA.C.1(3) Reinforcement in accordance with NS 3576 meets the requirements for characteristic material properties for use with this standard.
Reinforcement in accordance with NS-EN 10080 shall meet the requirements in (3), where the quantity, a, in formula (C.3) is set
The minimum and maximum values ascribed to the parameters, fyk, k and εuk, are given in Table NA.C.3N.

sec.label: NA.E.1
sec.title: General (indicative strength classes for durability)
sec.p: NA.E.1(2) A realistic expected strength for the actual durability class should be used in the design. The strength that may be expected for the various durability classes will among other factors be affected by the type of cement, the aggregate, and additives (silica, fly ash and slag). It will normally vary with local conditions and should therefore be specified for the individual project. In Table NA.E.1N, values are given that may represent a lower limit for expected strength. Therefore, it should not be assumed that the values for expected strength will be lower than those that are given in the table.

caption.title: Indicative lower values for expected strength for the various durability classes

sec.title: The use of informative annexes
sec.p: Annex A may be used as an informative annex with the provisions that are given in this National Annex.
Annex B is informative
Annex C is normative
Annex D is informative
Annex E is informative
Annex F is informative
Annex G is informative
Annex H is informative
Annex I is informative
Annex J may be used as an informative annex, with the following amendments:
J.1 Is not used
J.2.2(2) The angle θ is chosen so that: 0,4 ≤ tan θ ≤ 1,0
J.3(2) The factor k1 is set equal to 0,3
J.3(3) The factor k2 is set equal to 0,5
